story: My partner and I live in opposite sides of same house - with separate kitchensShelley, who has gone viral on TikTok, shared her blended household set up with her followers, which means she lives on one side of a house with her kids, while her partner lives on the opposite side with hisShelley shared her blended family set up on TikTok Image: TikTok Shelley LynnByJessica TaylorReal le features writer:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov | commentsA mum who lives with her children, her partner and his children in a blended household has ided opinion after sharing how they live on two separate sides of the same house. Shelley, who posts about her family le on TikTok, has gone viral after offering a glimpse into her family home - which looks normal enough from the outside. But when you walk in the front door, the structure of the house is dferent to any other - with two separate sides for each half of the family. The two suites are virtually identical which might seem odd to some, but Shelley says thereaposs method to the madness. She argues that, for her blended family of seven, the set up is perfect and allows them to live separately but together.For more of the news you care about straight to your inbox, sign up for one of our daily newsletters here In the video, which has racked up more than  million views, she showcases both sides of her ided home, which is kitted out with separate kitchens and bathrooms. She explains: My partner and I have five kids between us so we own a home that has two suites. We live separately, together. Blended, unblended. Shelley lives on one side of the house with her two kids, while her partner and his three children occupy the other side. “Iaposd love to find other families that live like this… I think it’s amazing - would you live like this ” she said. In another video, Shelley gives a more in-depth look into her side of the house, which is stunningly decorated and even has a walk-in wardrobe. She wrote: “Self-care is leaving my space exceptionally clean for my future self when I get back from a trip.” For the most part, people were pretty impressed by Shelleyaposs set up with her partner. One person said: Let’s normalise doing whatever makes people happy and is best for the kids. Others joked theyaposd like to implement a similar regime - but with the kids in one half and the adults in another. Some people praised Shelley for not forcing the step-siblings to be close just because the parents are together, and instead letting them each have their own space. However, others questioned why Shelley would want to separate her le from her partner - suggesting itaposs a pretty expensive way of living. Some people who commented on the post said they actually lived in a similar way, but for dferent reasons.Does your family have an unusual living arrangement  Tell us why it works for you! story: Britains most premature baby born outside hospital seeks paramedic who saved his leMatthew Kandziorra defied all odds after he was born more than  weeks early on the floor of his parents’ bathroom, weighing in at just g Matthew wants to track down the paramedic Image: MEN MEDIAByMirror ReporterEmma RosemurgeyAudience Writer:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov " data-content-image"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES s _MMH-Britains-most-premature-baby.jpg" data-tracking"facebook|share|top"" data-content-image"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES s _MMH-Britains-most-premature-baby.jpg" data-tracking"twitter|share|top"" data-content-image"https:i-prod.mirror incoming article.ece ALTERNATES s _MMH-Britains-most-premature-baby.jpg" data-tracking"whatsapp|share|top"| commentsThe most premature baby to survive being born outside of a hospital in the UK has launched an appeal to thank the paramedic who saved his le. Thought to be the only baby in the UK to have survived after being born so early outside of hospital, Matthew Kandziorra medically aposdiedapos in an ambulance en route to Leeds’ St Jamesaposs Hospital. Thankfully, the youngster was brought back from the brink after a heroic paramedic gave him le-saving CPR, all while his concerned parents looked on. Now , Matthew, who has Cerebral Palsy, hopes to find the dedicated medic who gave him a chance at le and thank him face-to-face. Get the news you want straight to your inbox.for a Mirror newsletter here Matthew said: The paramedic cut the umbilical cord and took me to the ambulance, unfortunately, on the short way to the hospital, I stopped breathing and died. But luckily the same heroic paramedic did CPR and saved my le. After all these years, I canapost stop thinking about this paramedic. I would like to find him and thank him. Matthewaposs mum Laura went into labour unexpectedly at just  weeks and four days at their Leeds home in the early hours of August , , having woken with stomach pain at around am.  His grandmother, Renata Sawicka, delivered him in the bathroom, all while his dad Dawid relayed instructions from a  operator. It soon became clear that there was no time to get Laura to the hospital before the birth. After Matthew arrived at the hospital, doctors fought tirelessly to save him, with the infant kept in hospital for four months after undergoing a blood transfusion. Much to their joy, Matthew’s parents were finally able to bring him home just in time for Christmas , by which point he weighed . kilos.  Through tears, Dawid recalled how the paramedic had come to visit Matthew and his family the very next day after his son was born: “He is a hero. He saved my sonaposs le. If I could see him I would say thank you”. The couple, who were both just twenty years old at the time of Matthew’s birth, were told by doctors at the time that their baby boy had suffered brain damage.The Mirror is committed to more hopeful news. title: cinema blasted refusing ask customers
story: Cinema blasted for refusing to ask customers for Covid pass saying its discriminatoryIndependent picture house, Cinema  Co, announced they will "take a stand" against the Welsh Governments Covid passports, which they consider "discriminatory and unlawful"Cinema  Co boss Anna Redfern called the Welsh Governments Covid pass discriminatory and unlawfulByRhodri HarrisonRyan FaheyReporter:,  Nov | comments An independent cinema is refusing to ask customers to present a Covid pass as they feel the scheme is discriminatory and illegal. Last week the Welsh Government announced the passports will be extended to cinemas, theatres and concert halls. Anna Redfern, who owns indie picture house Cinema  Co in Swansea, told her Facebook followers the new rules were the final nail in the coffin of what it sees as the killing [of] the entertainment industry. The cinema has vowed to take a stand against the new measures claiming they arediscriminatory and unlawful , Wales Online reports.Officials say the passes are will help keep the public safe and distanced from those infected with the virus.  The pass will come into force this week and will show whether the inidual has been vaccinated and tested. Cinema  Co said it will not be implementing the nonsensical  unnecessary Covid passports.The independent Cinema is the latest venue in the city centre to announce a direct stand against the Covid passports with aposThe Perchapos also making a change last month.In a post on their social media, Cinema  Co said: Dear Customers. As an independent business, we will not be implementing the nonsensical  unnecessary Covid passports here in Swansea, Wales as they are unlawful, an infringement of our human rights  discriminate against those exercising their right to bodily autonomy. Covid passes do not give freedom, they take it away. The decision has been met with criticism from people. Sian Beth hart said: Very disappointing attitude and may well backfire. The overwhelming majority approve of and have had their vaccines, and so are unlikely to frequent a venue that is trumpeting the anti-vaxxer brigade.  However, others praised the decision and hoped it would encourage more to follow suit.The decision was made by Anna Redfern, who transformed the venue into a foods and drink location earlier this year after ongoing battles with lockdown.Now the latest Covid Pass rules have been left unwelcome by the -year-old. She said: There are businesses that are skirting around the rules, people arenapost using them appropriately and the sheer knowledge that you have to have one of these is putting people off. People donapost want to come for this reason and this is why I wanted to say something and take a stand. Businesses are living in fear of losing their livelihoods and Iaposm in the exact same position, I didnapost want to pretend to comply anymore out of fear.  Being a single mum-of-two, Anna she has lived in fear over the past year and wanted to take a stand to stop the rules spreading into other industries. If this is the hill I am going to die on - then this is the hill Iaposm going to die on, she said. Iaposm standing up for what I believe in, it is not fair by any stretch of the imagination - it is killing the entertainment industry and hospitality is even next - it says so in the rules. Describing the new rules as discriminatory, Anna argued that her business has been repeatedly hit over the past year. They keep changing the goal posts, they keep putting up more obstacles and I have a right to earn a living, it puts food on my kids table and Iaposm a single mum, dealing with all this has been extremely challenging. Theres a huge discrimination element to these passes and people arenapost able to access their rights, weaposre in  and weaposre discriminating against those who have chosen to exercise bodily autonomy It just doesnapost fit right with me, people from all walks of le are welcome at Cinema  Co. First Minister Mark Drakeford announced the scheme last month, and said it was a measure suitable to deal with the sharp rise in Covid cases. title: girl 17 hounded home neighbours
story: Girl, , hounded from home by neighbours after reporting rapist to policeIn a statement the teenager said she is too terried to sleep following her ordeal at the hands of rapist Eric Stevenson, , from Middleton near RochdaleEric Stevenson was jailed for  years for raping a -year-old girl Image: Cavendish PressLtdByAlec Whitaker:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov A -year-old girl was hounded from her home after revealing to police she was raped by a man while his we was at church. The youngster was assaulted in her own home by Eric Stevenson, , who has been jailed for  years. Despite Stevenson being trapped by DNA evidence, locals in the girlaposs neighbourhood took sides with him and she was forced to moved away as a result. In a harrowing statement she said she is now too terried to sleep at night in her new home, and has lost friends following her ordeal. The teenager, who cannot be named for legal reasons, spoke out as Stevenson, from Middleton, near Rochdale, Greater Manchester was jailed. She said: “I have decided to speak so my abuser knows exactly how he made me feel because Iaposm sure he could see it in my eyes.  I have been scared to open up on my feelings but it was thought it might help give me closure and look forward. aposaposI have lost my friends as everyone around me was forced to take sides - and nobody chose me. I still feel so alone. I hate myself for feeling vulnerable and when I think about what happened to me, I feel sick and ashamed. aposaposI do not want to be a girl who has been abused. I want to be a normal -year-old girl who goes out with their friends but now I am too afraid. I am afraid of the dark and I am scared to leave the house. aposaposWhen I do, I look behind me every ten or so seconds. No one understands. Sometimes, I will have good days then something little happens like my brother or sister coming into my room without knocking and I get triggered. aposaposMy mum bought me a night light which I keep on because I’m afraid of the dark. This has helped but I still struggle to sleep some nights as I go over what has happened to me. I feel like I’m in a nightmare when I’m both awake and asleep. aposaposI’ve been made to feel worthless, angry, sad and hurt. I have lost everything. I am so alone with my thoughts that I have thought about ending things. I know that isn’t the way, I just want the pain to stop.” The investigation began in October  after the girl spoke to a teacher at her school and told her she had had raped the previous weekend. Jonathan Savage prosecuting said: aposaposThe defendant was interviewed by police officers and asked to comment on the allegations the complainant had made but denied he had done anything to her. aposaposBut the clothing she had been wearing over the course of the previous weekend was seized from her and this included the shorts she had been wearing. aposaposWhen the shorts were analysed, DNA was found on the inside of the front of the shorts and a trace of the defendant’s DNA was found on them.aposapos Stevenson who joined his we at the church after the attack, denied rape and assault but was convicted after a trial at Minshull Street Crown Court, Manchester. In mitigation defence counsel William Donnelly said: “This defendant is a man who has reached his mid s and who has signicant health problems. aposaposHe is a man of no previous convictions and a sentence of imprisonment will hit him hard and have lasting effects on him and his le.aposapos Sentencing Judge Paul Lawton told Stevenson: “What you did to her was quite appalling. It happened in her home, which she should have regarded as an entirely safe fair haven. As a consequence, she was compelled to leave in the days after what happened. “What you did to her will have caused incalculable damage for the rest of her le. We heard a heartfelt victim personal statement from her. She now faces a long term psychological battle as a result of your actions. She was particularly vulnerable and this was planned sexual abuse in the absence of your we.” Following his release from jail Stevenson will be on licence for an extra two years under the terms of an extended sentence. title: i turned every notification phone
story: I turned off every notication on my phone when I realised I was addictedFor the last six months Ive not had a single WhatsApp, email or tweet notication - my le is so much better for it, and my friends know Ill get back to them when I want, writes Lauren DudleyLauren doesnt even reply to her friends messages until shes ready - and says shes never felt better Image: Lauren DudleyopinionByLauren Dudley:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov | commentsSix months ago, my minute-by-minute habit was reaching out for a buzzing phone. Late-night emails, client WhatsApps, the news, a Twitter notication, FitBit… it didn’t matter what it was. What mattered is that I was immediately available or I’d miss something transformative, I was sure of it. I’d sit at dinner, discussing a friend’s hilariously bad date, missing cues to laugh as I was too busy urging myself not to glance down at my lit up screen. I’d sit at my desk, unable to focus, being pulled out of concentration by the incessant glow. I had reached such a heightened level of contact with the outside world that I didn’t even notice how badly I needed to disconnect. One day, after a long, hard think about this habit, I did something I never thought would actually stick: I turned every single notication off.You’d think I’d be the last person on earth to actually manage this, or I certainly did anyway. I had founded amarketing agencyin the year prior. I had clients, a small team, umpteen social media accounts to manage, inquiring journalists, potential business popping up and I really believed this demanded me to be non-negotiably on, all the time. Would you ever go cold turkey on your phone notications  Have your say in the comments below Fast forward six months, I now find it incredibly odd to imagine my phone holding that much power over me. I’ve turned off every single notication, I don’t open the email app out-of-hours, and I’ve turned off the banner and badge alerts for most apps too. Nothing, except urgent phone calls, has lit up my phone for over half a year. The first two weeks were uncomfortably dficult. When you get a notication, it triggers a dopamine rush, and my own brain was addicted to this “reward”, craving the habit-based behaviour. I felt anxious for a while, semi-desperately telling everyone about it, making sure they knew to call they needed me.After that  Peace. There’s been a million ways this has benefited me in every aspect of my le but perhaps most importantly, I am able to be present, no matter where I am. Whether it’s getting my head down to plan a brand launch strategy or at the dinner table discussing future travel plans. Either way, I am finally living in the moment. People rarely call, and this always surprises me. Both my colleagues and I have realised that we believe everything is urgent, until we’re forced to decideit’s worth interrupting someone... and it often turns out, it’s just not. Clients follow the same logic. I’m a big fan of that. I can’t think of one single moment or opportunity I have missed because of this. Everyone, both professionally and personally, has better boundaries with me now. Our clients rarely WhatsApp, butand when they do, I still won’t reply out of working hours, unless itaposs an emergency - which is almost never. My friends know I’ll reply when I can , but they also know when I’m with them, I’m now both physically and mentally present. As a society, we have a painful and damaging relationship with technology, and an ever-growing notion that with all this wonderful tech, we should be far more connected than ever before. It’s undeniable that we’re privileged to have this access. But at the same time, being instantly available to everyone and anything is simply not healthy.My current wellbeing is testament to that. I used to feel anxious and overwhelmed, and while this might not be the only change I made to lessen that, it’s certainly one of the biggest. It’s liberating. I’ve learnt that you don’t ever need to apologise for being unavailable. You don’t need to give anyone that instant access to you. You don’t need to be actively busy to not respond - you’re entitled to be actively not-busy and still unavailable. Those boundaries are healthy and should become society’s norm. And I truly believe,you challenge yourself to three weeks, this will become your norm too. news uk-news kate-middleton-proves-shes-queen-"Kate Middleton: Monarchy ‘realise the power of Kate’ says punditByJenner NewtonRoyal Features Writer:,  Nov | comments From the day she married future King Prince William, the Duchess of Cambridge has been primed to become the future Queen.Now  years on from their wedding and three children later, Kate has become, as one royal expert puts it, one of the most powerful royals right now. Recently, sheaposs taken on more duties and patronages and has spoken out on powerful issues such as child development in the early years and addiction.Signicantly, she also took the centre spot in the middle of the Duchess of Cornwall and Countess of Wessex on the balcony as they watched the Remembrance Sunday service at the Cenotaph this year. Here we look at how Kate is appearing to be a Queen in waiting... We and mother One way in which Kate has become a power player in the royal family is her role as we of a future king and mother to a future king. And according to royal expert Camilla Tominey, this makes her arguably the most powerful person in the royal family. Love the royals for the Mirroraposs daily newsletter to get all the latest news on the Queen, Charles, Kate, Wills, Meghan, Harry and the rest of The Firm. Click here to sign up.In a video for the , she said: When it comes to their generation, you could say [Kate and Prince William] are ruling the royal roost. Meanwhile, according to royal author Katie Nicholl, there are t wo roles for a future Queen, and Kate has already fulfilled one.She told the documentary Kate: The Making of a Modern Queen: One is to produce heirs, which she has done and one is to learn to one day become Queen. More duties With the death of the Duke of Edinburgh and the elderly Queen scaling back her engagements, Kate has appeared to step up and take on more responsibility and work as she prepares to become consort. Meanwhile, Prince Harry and Meghan Markle stepping down from the royal family has also thrust Kate into the spotlight more.One Palace staffer previously said: “Without a doubt, we are in a period of change. Arguably change at the top, with the Queen handing over more responsibilities to the Prince of Wales and, of course, William. What does that mean for Kate “It means she will be even more front and centre, and what you’ve seen over the past year or two is that she definitely has grown in confidence in order to do that. “With the Duke and Duchess of Sussex out of the picture, and never likely to , one would think this is their time. “At one stage they may have thought that they were being over-burdened but in reality they have a clear run. “They can work on the projects they want to and which they feel can make the most impact. But they can also carry on the work of the monarchy in their own way, upholding the values of those who came before them while making it relevant for a new generation. It’s going to be a very exciting time.” Growing confidence  As Kate takes on more and more engagements, experts have noted her growing with confidence.And at the weekendaposs Remembrance Sunday commemorations at the Cenotaph, it was notable she stood in the middle with Camilla and Sophie on either side of her as they watched the service from a balcony.And according to body language expert Judi James, she very much looked like the highest-ranking woman in the group. She told the Express : With Camilla next in line to the role of Queen consort it might have been expected for her to take that middle position between the two younger women.“Eventhere’s no actual protocol the non-verbal message is rather emphatic and by standing to one side like this it gives the impression that Kate is very much the Queen’s stand-in at this event. “Kate’s height and her body language give her a very natural look of royal high status and the way she rotates to speak to Sophie and Camilla in turns adds to this impression of being female alpha in the group. Family peacemaker  However, it appears that as well as stepping up when it comes to duties, Kate has also stepped in to help with family matters.Experts have hailed her increasing role as a peacemaker between the Firm and the Sussexes, following the latteraposs fractious move to America and a series of explosive interviews criticising the royals.Kateaposs skilful handling of the crisis was on full display at Prince Philipaposs funeral in April, as she was seen walking with feuding brothers Prince William and Prince Harry before quietly stepping away to allow them a rare chance to talk.  Insiders have even suggested she is stepping into the Duke of Edinburghaposs shoes as the family aposconfidanteapos.In an interview on  Minutes Australia, expert Katie Nicholl suggested that Kate was now best positioned to take up the Dukeaposs mantle.I think Kate is the glue. In the same way that the Duke of Edinburgh was always the one who would help resolve family issues, she said. He was the patriarch of the family. She added: I see Kate stepping into that role. Trying to keep things together. Meanwhile, writing in the Sunday aposs Stella magazine, Camilla Tominey said the mum-of-three was fast becoming recognised for how regal an operator she is. She wrote: Her skilful handling of royal crises in recent months suggests that she is fast emerging as the jewel in the monarchyaposs crown. title: kids over 12 must wait
story: Kids over  must wait  months to get jab after Covid due to very small heart riskOfficials have decided to give kids the -week delay due to the "very, very small" potential for patients to develop the little-understood symptom of heart inflammationUK regulators have decided to give children under  a three-month buffer period between Covid infection and vaccinationImage: Getty ImagesByMartin BagotHealth and Science editor:,  Nov | comments Children aged  and over must wait  weeks after any Covid- infection before they get vaccinated.UK regulators have decided on the delay because of the “very, very small” risk of a little understood side effect of heart inflammation. Health officials say current case rates of myocarditis after vaccination among under s are around nine per million vaccinations and cases have been “relatively mild”. However the -week rule will lead to signicant delays in rolling out the vaccine programme among children.Around half of school children have had Covid- and yesterday’s REACT- study showed one in  pupils were infected between October  and November .  The current advice for older people and for people at high risk of Covid- - including those aged  and over - is that they should wait four weeks between Covid infection and having a dose of vaccine. But officials said this should be extended to  weeks in lower-risk children between  and . The guidance comes amid high infection rates among younger age groups. It is thought that a natural Covid- infection in younger people provides them with “at least” three months’ protection and could extend to six months. On Monday, the Joint Committee on Vaccination and Immunisationsaid  and -year-olds could book their second Covid- vaccine  weeks after their first. But the UKHSA said that should teenagers in this age group be infected with Covid- after their first dose, they should then delay the second dose until  weeks after the infection. news uk-news liverpool-bombers-only--words-"Final journey of Liverpool Womens Hospital bomber captured on CCTVByPaul ByrneLucy ThorntonDanya Bazaraa:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov The Liverpool taxi bomber had spoken only two words during the journey before the explosion outside the Liverpool Womenaposs Hospital. Hero taxi driver David Perry had a miracle escape after a home-made device strapped to his passenger Emad Jamil Al Swealmeen - who changed his name to Enzo Almeni - exploded in the back of his cab outside the hospital on Sunday.Chilling shop CCTV footage has been published by the Liverpool Echo showing the final journey of Almeni on his way to sow terror at the hospital.This comes after a source close to the driver told the Mirror the bomber only spoke two words - “Women’s hospital” - after he was picked up for the seven minute car journey shortly before am on Remembrance Sunday.  He didn’t say another word all the way there. The driver was not aware of anything” said the source. He said David was briefly knocked out by the force of the blast, which blew out his windscreen and sent shards of glass and metal spiralling in the air. The source added: “He woke up leaning on the steering wheel. He was trapped and then saw flames coming through the two seats. “He couldn’t get his seatbelt off so had to climb out of it.”  David was able to scramble free seconds before his car was engulfed by flames with Almeni still inside. His we said later her husband was saved by “ angels”. The Liverpool Echo learned that Mr Perryaposs taxi travelled along Lodge Lane on its way to the Crown Street site, and was captured by cameras at The Green Mountain Food Store, by the junction with Tagus Street. Manager Naz Al-Asadi, , told them: The police came in around pm yesterday, they said to me can we check the CCTV. I said yes, we should work together as this is something not good at all, this is very, very bad. They knew the time and they took a copy. It is very horrible, very very bad. I just want to know what was going on with this guy, it is not normal.  Four men arrested in relation to the explosion outside the Womenaposs Hospital in Liverpool on Sunday  November have now been released from custody following interview. Assistant Chief Constable Russ Jackson, said in an update on Monday: Following interviews with the arrested men, we are satisfied with the accounts they have provided and they have been released from police custody. The investigation continues to move at a fast pace with investigative teams working throughout the night. We have made signicant progress since Sunday morning and have a much greater understanding of the component parts of the device, how they were obtained and how the parts are likely to have been assembled. We have also recovered important evidence from the address at Rutland Avenue which is becoming central to the investigation.  There is a considerable way to go to understand how this incident was planned, prepared for and how it happened. We are gaining a better understanding by the hour but it is likely to be some time, perhaps many weeks until we are confident on our understanding of what has taken place. In the meantime, we have considerable resources and staff deployed to understand how this device was built and whoanyone  was involved. If the evidence takes us to the involvement of others, further arrests will quickly take place. Anyone who has any information should call on    quoting Liverpool Womens Hospital incident. -year-old from Childwall had worked in the WH Smith at the hospital for around -months before starting his new job as an Asda delivery driver a few weeks ago, Liverpool Echo reported. Liam and Stephanie, , were driving into Liverpool city centre when he decided to stop off at the hospital and say hello to his old colleagues. Liam said: I thought Iaposll just swing by and say hello to everyone. I pulled up and said I should only be five or  minutes and told for her to wait . Liam said: I thought, aposOh s**tapos because the car next to mine had started to go on fire. I thoughtmy car goes up it will take the whole hospital so I thought Iaposll try and move it. Emergency services arrived and put out the flames and police secured the car park and front entrance of the hospital. story: Mum of UKs biggest family The Radfords shows off stunning hair transformationMum-of- Sue Radford of Morecambe, Lancashire, said her hair feels "so much healthier" after making a big change to her usually dark, straight hair with blonde tipsMum of Britains largest family, Sue Radford, from Morecambe, Lancashire, has changed her hairstyle and says she feels so much betterByJon MacphersonRyan FaheyReporter:,  Nov | comments The mum of Britainaposs biggest family has shown off her stunning style transformation which has made her hair feel so much healthier. Sue Radford has made a subtle but effective change to her appearance, Lancs Live reports. The -year-old mum, who has  children, is usually seen sporting dark, straight hair with blond tips.But Sue has opted for a change, and has snipped off her locks and now has a sleek bob with honey-coloured highlights.Sue, who is married to husband Noel, unveiled the new look in an Instagram story for her , doting followers.  Sue captioned the picture: My hair feels so much healthier. The makeover comes as Sue begins Christmas shopping for her huge family and setting up decorations in their Morecambe home. Last week she visited Hayes Garden World in Ambleside with her mum to “have a look” at the Christmas decorations.  Earlier this month she announced the start of her festive season splurge with orders made to Smyths Toys. Each year Sue, from Morecambe, Lancashire, normally spends around £, on presents for family, friends and loved ones and also budgets £ for their festive meal.The couple have  children and seven grandchildren and have been carrying out an epic transformation of their home since the beginning of this year.In a vlog posted on November , Sue said she had her eye on a Christmas tree at Ambleside Garden Centre for “a little while” so was keen to “see what itaposs like” before purchasing it for the festive season, LancashireLive reports.She said: “I’m hoping it gets me in the Christmas mood because I’m not really feeling it at the minute. “I think itaposs probably because maybe itaposs a bit early.”  She then explained to both the viewers and son, Archie, that she wants to buy a new Christmas tree for the living room and the old tree can go into the dining room. The family live in a -bed former care home in Morecambe which has been newly renovated. Sue took viewers around the garden centre and pointed out a range of Christmas decorations, including owls that can sit on the Christmas tree and some giant toadstools.  She bagged a couple of toadstool baubles for £. as well as some red flowers to sit on the tree. Revealing their Christmas decoration plans for the newly renovated house, she said: “I think this year it’s going to be pink in the dining room, because obviously I’ve got pink chairs, and then red in my living room, so I’m going to do that, it’ll look good.” She also picked up some pink baubles for the dining room tree and took viewers along on the shop with her. story: Mum who doesnt have injections sacked from care worker job for refusing Covid jabDevastated mum Holly Higgins, , claims she is medically exempt after being told she needs to be vaccinated to keep her job at Appleton Manor care home in Manchester - but bosses disagreedHolly Higgins told bosses she wouldnt get the Covid- jab and believed she was exempt Image: Holly HigginsByPaige OldfieldSam Elliott-Gibbs:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov | comments A mum who claims she has always refused injections is planning to take a care home to an employment tribunal after being unfairly sacked. Holly Higgins told bosses she wouldnapost get the Covid- vaccine but they said she either had to back down or lose her job.The -year-old, a healthcare assistant at Appleton Manor in Bredbury, Manchester, for almost four years, says she should have been medically exempt following the announcement of the mandate.She submitted proof of ious medical issues to her employees before the government deadline, theManchester Evening News reports.But her pleas fell on deaf ears - and she is now out of work with Christmas fast approaching.The parent believes working through the pandemic led to her developing a number of health problems and she wants to take the matter further.  She said: “I’ve had my heart ripped out - I’ve had to leave the residents Iaposve looked after for three and a half years. I feel so worthless. “I feel like we weren’t valued at all throughout the pandemic. “And now to be last year’s heroes and this year’s unemployed – itaposs totally unfair.” She believes she now has asthma and allergies after working as the pandemic raged - issues she never suffered from previously. Holly, who also suffers with anxiety, says being allowed exemption from the vaccine was denied. She continued: “I had a meeting in August as I was the one who wasn’t vaccinated. I suffer from anxiety so became distressed in the meeting and they didn’t care. “They told meI didn’t have the vaccine, I would be dismissed. I suffer from anxiety so became distressed in the meeting and they didn’t care. I’m going to try and tribunal it. “All of this is causing stress and anxiety to my le. I haven’t signed anything in my contract to say I’d have a vaccine. “I’ve refused the flu jab every time I’ve been there. I just don’t have any injections so Iaposm not going to make an exception for Covid. Whataposs the point when you can still catch it. “A vaccine doesn’t make you the person you are today. It’s whether you care or you don’t. “Why it’s a level of requirement now – it’s bonkers.” A spokesperson for HC-One, who run Appleton Manor, said: “Our purpose is to be The Kind Care Company, supporting our residents to lead their best le with care from our experienced and passionate Colleagues. Our homes need to be safe and open to visiting so that residents and their families can come together as they wish. “We can’t miss any opportunity to make this happen, which is why we announced in July that the Covid- vaccine would be a condition of employment for all HC-One employees across the nations. This was the responsible step for us to take to protect the people we care for, as well as our colleagues, as the evidence clearly shows that vaccination cuts transmission and substantially reduces the risk of hospitalisation.With so much changing so quickly, keep on top of what is happening with the Mirroraposs news updates by email. Delivered straight to your inbox, our daily coronavirus briefing will keep you informed of what is happening with Covid, lockdown, the vaccination rollout and the impact on how we live.here. The introduction of the Government’s legislation in England on  November means that HC-One now also has a legal duty to ensure that all colleagues in our homes across England are either fully vaccinated or have a valid medical exemption in line with the Government’s guidance. “Since the vaccination programme started, we have worked tirelessly to support colleagues to choose to be vaccinated, and are pleased with the high vaccination take up we have seen in all our homes. Since the mandate was announced, we have made every effort to explain the consequences to colleagues who choose not to be vaccinated, and who do not have a valid medical exemption. We have engaged at , including on a one-to-one basis, with colleagues and their representatives to understand their inidual reasons for not receiving the vaccine. “We expect to lose a small proportion of colleagues who have chosen to remain unvaccinated without qualying medical exemptions. We expect this number to be less than , from our colleague population of over ,. title: mum who scoffed cheese pregnancy
story: Mum who scoffed cheese in pregnancy says obsessed toddler now wont eat anything Maddy Alexander-Grout, , and her husband James, , say their fussy daughter Harriet, "turns her nose up" at anything other than her favourite food, cheeseFussy toddler Harriet Alexander-Grout, from Southampton, is obsessed with cheese after her mum scoffed on cheddar during her pregnancy Image: Kennedy News and MediaByRebecca CooleyRyan FaheyReporter:,  Nov | commentsA mum believes that scoffing cheese while pregnant has caused her aposstubbornapos toddler to become addicted to cheddar.Maddy Alexander-Grout, , and husband James, , say they have tried apos every meal in the world involving cheese apos to feed their fussy two-year-old daughter Harriet. The mum-of-two thinks the totaposs bizarre obsession comes from her guzzling large amounts of cheese during pregnancy. And now Maddy says she is forced to grate cheese over vegetables. If she didnapost, the toddler wouldnapost eat anything healthy. But Harriet is the youngest of a family of cheese lovers, who claim to have been the number one purchaser of the dairy delight from Sainsburyaposs in Southampton.The exasperated mum-of-two refuses to give up on her daughteraposs extremely restrictive diet and says she will continue to explore dferent foods with the fussy tot. Maddy, from Shirley, Southampton, said: She will eat everythingitaposs cheese and nothing , sheaposs a pain. But itaposs not like she likes all kinds of cheese - basically anything cheddar or cheddar-form, thataposs it! She says aposI love cheese mummy, I want cheese mummy, please can I have cheese mummyapos - that sort of thing all the time, and cheese is aposyummyapos and anything  is aposyuckyapos. Itaposs so hard to feed her, sheaposs a stubborn little one. We have basically had every meal in the world involving cheese. I put other things on her plate all the time so that she can try them and investigate but itaposs always a no and the dog ends up eating most of it. I absolutely love cheese as well. Weaposre a very cheesy family, apart from my son who hates it, so we buy at least four blocks of cheese a week. On the Nectar app for Sainsburys you can look at what your top purchases are for and from that I know that at one point we were the top purchaser of cheese in Southampton. The mum says her toddleraposs typical meals include cheese on toast, cheese omelettes and cheesy pasta, while her favourite cheesy snacks are cheese and crackers, Wotsits, Quavers and Cheese Strings. Meanwhile any non-cheese food items usually end up being thrown to the family dog Dexter, a seven-year-old Spaniel, after Harriet refuses to eat them. Maddy suspects that her diet during pregnancy may have influenced her daughteraposs aposobsessionapos with cheese, as she suffered from gestational diabetes and was advised to eat more cheese. Gestational diabetes is high blood sugar that develops during pregnancy because the body canapost produce enough insulinto meet the extra demands of pregnancy.The NHS advises women who suffer from the condition to eat three portions of calcium-rich foods, such as cheese, daily - leading Maddy to believe this is when her daughter got a taste for cheddar. Maddy, who is the founder of a free parenting advice app called aposParenthoodapos, said: Itaposs weird because I had gestational diabetes when I was pregnant so I ate lots of cheese and now Iaposm wondering whether or not it could be connected. With gestational diabetes you have to eat high fat to keep your blood sugars low and cheese is one of the things they suggest. Cheese was all I ate when I was pregnant so maybe I got her into that habit. When we were doing baby-led weaning and putting food in front of her she loved these really tiny cheese cubes and she went for those over everything . Anything  you put in front of her she would turn her nose up at, she doesnapost want to eat it. Despite the stresses of trying to feed their extremely picky child, the parents say they havenapost given up entirely and will continue to offer little Harriet a iety of nutrient rich foods in the hopes of finding more things she will eat. Although so far her exclusive love of cheese has prevailed and the dog continues to enjoy an array of tit-bits. Maddy said: We try very hard to mix it up a bit so she might have macaroni cheese or vegetables with cheese on, but we literally have to grate cheese over everything. Itaposs pretty dficult but we havenapost given up completely. We are still putting fruit on her plate. We do try but most things she turns her nose up at. I donapost think sheaposs necessarily scared of other foods but she just has such an affection for cheese that it just comes first. fears of the nation over the Queen’s health by today insisting “she’s alright”. The Prince of Wales was asked about his mother’s health during an engagement in Amman, Jordan, where he is on tour with the Duchess of Cornwall this week. The Queen’s unexpected absence from the Remembrance Day ­service sparked concerns, but he reassured the public there is nothing to read into her withdrawal. Her Majesty has been resting under doctors’ orders since spending the night in hospital on October , after undergoing “preliminary investigations” for an unknown condition.  Today she told General Sir Nick Carter, Chief of the Defence Staff, it was easier to continue once you get into the top military job as she carried out her first official engagements since missing the Remembrance Sunday service. The head-of-state, the nationaposs longest reigning sovereign and has herself been in the principal royal role of monarch for nearly  years, pledging her whole le to royal service. Buckingham Palace has said the Queen has been in good spirits despite taking a back step from public duties for the last few weeks and today she smiled and chatted to General Sir Nick.  After hearing the military man had been in the post for the second longest in history, the Queen remarked: I supposeyou get into that job, you know, it is easier to continue, isnapost it really The monarch, who was without her walking stick, was pictured standing in the castleaposs Oak Room, having pulled out of attending the Cenotaph ceremony three days ago due to a sprained back. The Queen chuckled and replied: Oh really  Oh   She added: I supposeyou get into that job, you know, it is easier to continue, isnapost it really  Gen Sir Nick said: I think thataposs right. Although I have to say I think the time comes when itaposs ready to move on. After chatting together standing up, the pair went on to sit in nearby chairs to continue their conversation. It is the first time in nearly a month that the Queen has been pictured carrying out an in-person engagement since she hosted a reception for the global investment summit at Windsor on October . She held a face to face audience with Prime Minister Boris Johnson last week but was not pictured doing so. It was the second of two audiences the Queen held on Wednesday. Buckingham Palace said the head of state earlier met virtually with Commanding Officers of the Royal Scots Dragoon Guards via video link. story: Universal Credit loan: Emergency £, loan could be yours in time for ChristmasChristmas is on the way, bringing with it financial uncertainties of how to get through the season. But respite could be available for those who qualy for an interest free loanA little known scheme for Universal Credit claimants could ease some money worries, with interest free loans of up to £, Image: PAByTom HaynesKate BuckNews Reporter:,  Nov | commentsChristmas is fast approaching, bringing with it a raft of money worries for many families about how they will cope financially with the festive season.But a little known scheme for Universal Credit claimants could ease some money worries, with interest free loans of up to £, for those who are waiting for their first payment to come through. The loan can also be accessed by those who need more money due to a sudden change in circumstances, like having a baby, MyLondon reports. Universal Credit claimants are facing a tougher time than ever after the temporary uplt given during lockdown was snatched away in October, just as increases in energy and food costs starting biting at peopleaposs pockets.  Those making a claim for Universal Credit face a five-week wait for the money, which can leave some struggling for cash to pay bills. The advance payment is currently being offered via the Department for Work and Pensions , which will allow claimants to borrow money then pay it back in installments. The loans are interest free - and the amount claimants can get depends on how much Universal Credit they are entitled to. The maximum amount claimants can borrow is currently £,. Claimants can as for up to  per cent of the amount but can also ask for less.  Borrowed money should be with claimants within three days of making a claim and will have to make the money last five weeks until the UC payment comes through. The money deducted from your next UC payment can be worked out by iding the full cost by Claimants who get a job and stop claiming UC will still have to repay the loan. Those wishing to make a claim should apply through JobCentre   . Applications made because of a change in circumstance should be done over the phone. Applicants will need to explain their reasons for needing the loan - and wonapost get the payment automatically. They will also need to be able to prove that they can pay back the cash, and agree a rate at which the loan will be repaid. Those struggling to repay an advance will be able to pause a repayment for up to three months . Applicants are advised to contact their work coach or ask online for further assistance. title: what its really like working
story: What its REALLY like working at McDonalds Drive-Thru - panic alarm to secret camerasIve caught staff crying in the freezer and behind the bins during the obligatory mid-sht breakdown - spare a thought for us the next time you order your p cheeseburger, writes McDonalds Drive-Thru worker Dom Lee*We can see and hear everything you do while youre waiting to give your order at the speakers Image: Getty ImagesopinionByDom Lee:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov | commentsThere’s nothing more rewarding than a towering Big Mac accompanied by salty , hotfries from a McDonald’s Drive-Thru on a Friday night. But while this treat might feel like heaven, believe me, itaposs Hell working there. Whether it’s the medley of teenage lads shouting “Here comes Fatty” to me as they scoff a p cheeseburger, or the experience of witnessing a grown man rip off a Covid- protection window due to a lack of milkshakes, my six years at McDonalds have been nothing short of a flurry. After applying fresh out of high school , McDonald’s flexible hours and healthy rate of pay was extremely attractive to a skint first-year college student. And while most worry the lack of experience would be the issue with younger staff members, it’s the drama you’ve got to watch out for.  Once you’re past the three-month probation - during which most existing staff members refuse to acknowledge your existence - every fresh cohort brings a brand-new tier to Macciesapos ever growing political chain. However, the real initiation isn’t complete without the obligatory mid-sht breakdown. I can’t tell you how many people I’ve caught crying in the freezer, the stock room, even behind the bins. It’s a rite of passage for new staff members. Keeping a brave face is at least  percent of the job. From the Friday stampede of orders , to shovelling the remnants of half-chewed chicken nuggets from abandoned trays into the bin, and even having abuse hurledfor receiving cold food “after waiting for half an hour” always half an hour.It’s all just a part of the job.  That’s not to say every customer is rude, though. But there are the ones who test patience in a busy Drive-Thru. Firstly, nothing is LESS funny than when people try and order a Wicked Zinger Box Meal. Secondly, on behalf of every McDonald’s worker, we don’t serve mayonnaise. I don’t know why we don’t serve mayonnaise I don’t know IF we will ever serve mayonnaise and “speaking to the manager” about the lack of mayonnaise certainly isn’t going to solve anything. Thirdly, we can hear and see everything you do while you’re waiting to give your order by the Drive-Thru speakers. I can’t tell you how many solo renditions of cringe ‘s pop hits I’ve heard over the years. Alas, the serenade of freshly driving teens and those who queue for half an hour for the sake of a bottle of waterblocks out the eight hours of incessant beeping machines. *The writeraposs name has been changed. The mum-of-four also claims her now ex-husband cheated on her with at least  dferent woman throughout the duration of their marriage and even had two children with two dferent women while married to Hailey. Hailey, who works in administration said: I heard rumours that my friend was pregnant and homeless, so I reached out to her. I felt the need to help her. We are all charismatic people, so we all had that nature to be charismatic around each other and make jokes. I didnapost see anything there. I was very naive so I just didnapost think it would be possible for someone to do that. We had just got home from the hospital and I was changing the baby when she turned her neck the birth defect popped out. story: Im a hospice nurse - this is what people often say right before they dieJulie McFadden, a registered nurse from Los Angeles, in Calornia, has worked in a hospice for more than five years, and often shares her unique experiences on social mediaThe nurse discussed peoples final moments Image: hospicenursejulie TiktokByRosaleen FentonAudience Writer:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov | commentsLooking after a family member who is unwell is always tough, and when the day comes that they pass away, it can be one of the worst times of your le. Some people canapost face being in the same room when a loved one passes away - but one hospice nurses account of what most people say before they die might change your mindthat sounds like you. While one of the phrases is to be expected, the other may leave you a bit heartbroken.Julie McFadden @hospicenursejuliehas worked as a nurse hospice for five years after previously working in the ICU for more than a decade. Get the news you want straight to your inbox.for a Mirror newsletter here She now also records TikTokaposs about her job and says she is keen to educate people on death, and how to prepare for it ahead of time.Speaking to The Sun, she said: The best part about my job is educating patients and families about death and dying as well as supporting them emotionally and physically.Also, helping them to understand what to expect is another part of my job as a hospice nurse. Talking about peopleaposs final moments, she explained: “There is something most people say before they die and it’s usually ‘I love you’ or they call out to their mum or dad - who have usually already died.” She also recently discussed some of the things that can happen at the end of a personaposs le that look aposabnormal,apos but are aposactually really normal. These include changes in breathing, changes in skin colour, aposterminal secretionsapos and fevers, which people may not expect. Prompted by her viewers, the experienced nurse said most people naturally dying in a hospice show the same signs and symptoms. .Julie explained: “The symptoms of the actively dying phase include changes inconsciousness , changes in breathing, mottling and terminal secretions.“These are normal and not painful or uncomfortable. Our bodies take care of ourselves at the end of le - the less we intervene, the better.” The dedicated nurse has said that sheaposs glad to have a  to educate people about death - and the vital support that a hospice can offer a whole family. “I want to normalise death by educating people about it. I went home to visit my family,and my tween nieces were on TikTok making dance videos, she explained. I later went on TikTok to see their dances. This gave me the idea of starting my ownTikTok about death and dying, four days later I did it and it took off. title: couple use overseas surrogate baby
story: Couple use overseas surrogate to have baby girl then abandon her , miles awayA couple used a surrogate to have the child last year but left the girl with her nanny before flying off to their home country and never coming back - now the nanny is being forced to give the child up for adoptionThe little girl, now  months old, has been in the care of the nanny and raised as her own daughter Image: NewsflashByLeonie Chao-Fong:,  Nov A couple used a surrogate to have a baby then abandoned her in another country , miles away. The parents travelled to Ukraine in August  after their baby was born to a surrogate mother. But for reasons unknown, the pair ed to their home country of Italy shortly after and left the new born behind, in the care of her nanny. While they promised tothey never came back to get her and so the little girl, now  months old, was cared for by the nanny who raised her as her own daughter. Realising the parents might notand worried about the legal repercussions, the nanny contacted the Italian consulate to report that she could no longer afford to raise the child. Italian authorities at the Juvenile Prosecutor’s Office were able to track down the parents and confirm that the couple did not intend to take their daughter back. Now, a court has determined that the little girl should be put up for adoption, leaving the nanny devastated that she will have to give her up. Ukraine is among a handful of countries in which surrogacy is commercial and legal and the country offers a systematic and large-scale provision of surrogate services to the world. A shocking video last year showed almost  surrogate babies crammed in a dormitory at a hotel in Kiev as the lockdown stopped their parents from collecting them.The parents from the UK, USA, Italy, Spain, France, Israel, Germany, China, Mexico, Romania and other countries had paid between £, and £, for services from an organisation that assisted them with starting families. But due to the pandemic causing countries to close their borders, the baby were being cared for by staff at a so-called aposbaby factoryapos. Last week, the Service for International Police Cooperationcoordinated with the Italian Consulate in the Ukrainian capital to organise for the baby to be taken to Italy and put up for adoption. A team that consisted of officials from the Italian Red Cross, including a paediatrician and volunteer nurse, travelled to Ukraine to fly the girl to Italy. The child was flown to Malpensa, on November  where she is currently being cared for by a foster family while the adoption process is underway. Carolina Casini, a volunteer pediatrician of the Italian Red Cross, told the court that the baby had slept for the entire duration of the trip in her arms. Although the team had been afraid of finding her in poor condition and emotionally deprived, they found that the little girl was in good condition and that the nanny who looked after her until yesterday loved her very much and took great care of her.”  The nanny was reported to have been heartbroken by the news and handed over pictures for the girl’s new parents so she will see them when she is grown up. The last recommendation from the nanny to the inspector who took the child back to Italy was: “Sheaposll eat the banana, give her a whole one.” It is unclear whether the surrogate parents will face prosecution for allegedly abandoning their baby daughter in Ukraine. story: " Ninja Prairie Dog! by Arthur Trevino Image:antHilarious photos from Comedy Wildle Photography Awards - from ninja dog to dancing cubsThe image of the brave prairie dog taking on an aerial assassin was shortlisted for the Comedy Wildle Photography Awards  - which was won by Brit Ken Jensen from BurnleyByMatt YellandKelly-Ann MillsReporterRyan Fahey:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov | commentsThis bald eagle got more than he bargained for when he tried to grab a prairie dog in Colorado, USA.The little guy attempted to take on the impressive bird in a real David and Goliath battle.The image was one of those shortlisted for the Comedy Wildle Photography Awards , which was snapped up by Brit Ken Jensen from Burnley.His shot of a golden silk monkey in Yunnan, China looks a tad painful - but hes actually adopting a fighting pose.Among the other images battling it out for the award was a pigeon whose flight plans were foiled by an autmunal leaf. Another highly-rated snap showed a group of gossiping raccoons, holding up their claws to their snouts as they lean in to share a secret. The awards started as a modest photo competition in  - based on the experiences of its founders after spending decades in East Africa. story: Girl severely burnt after beautician spilled hot wax and said stop making a big dealBadesim Kubak was  when she went for a routine leg wax, but was left needing weeks of treatment after she was left with horric burns when the wax went wrongBadesim Kubak, who is from Turkey but now lives New York, said she wanted her legs waxed for a concert, as her culture frowned on shaving Image: badesim TikTokByKate BuckNews Reporter:,  Nov Updated:,  Nov | commentsA woman has claimed a beautician left her with horric burns down her legs after spilling boiling wax on her during a routine treatment. Badesim Kubak, who is from Turkey but now lives New York, said she wanted her legs waxed for a concert, as her culture frowns on shaving. But what should have been an easy appointment caused her to need three weeks of medical treatments for the burns left by the wax. In a TikTok she wrote: Starting with waxing my legs, itaposs painful but I can take it. While the lady is applying the wax to my inner thighs, the lid of the applicator comes off and boiling wax spills all over between my legs. She added the wax spilled just inches from her vagina, and she started screaming and crying from the excruciating pain. But instead of stopping the treatment to seeshe was ok, or check what she had done, Badesim claims the beautician told her she was making a big deal out of it, and told her everything was ok. She rips the wax off me to stop it from burning my skin, while telling me it is seriously nothing, Badesim continued. aposShe puts MOISTURISER and PAPER TOWELS on my burn and tells me she is done. I am super embarrassed that everyone  in the salon heard me scream and cry.apos Without knowing what  to do, Badesim paid full price for her botched wax and went back to school, where a nurse tried to help as best they could. But the following morning it became clear the situation was more serious than initially thought, and was far more serious than the beautician said it would be. Next morning I wake up with insane pain, my leg is still wrapped up, she continued. My parents take me to my uncle who is a plastic surgeon to check it out.  Once the bandages came off the full extent of the injury became clear. She shared a picture of the injuries she received, showing the horrendous burn down her thigh. The video has since had over . million views, and Badesim filmed a part two video to answer questions about the incident asked by her horried followers. In it she said: My family and I were very shocked to see what was underneath the bandages, we were not expecting that at all. My uncle was surprised that I didnapost pass out from pain but I guess that was because she kept telling me I was making a big deal out of it, so I kind of just sucked it up. The following two-three weeks I had to go to my uncleaposs clinic every single day becausea burn like that gets infected it could end up horrible. I couldnapost walk properly for a while either because just putting pressure on that leg hurt. In another follow up video Badesim said her leg had healed nicely, and you could only see what had happenedyou looked very closely. She also explained why she decided not to sue the beautician - but added she regrets not taking action at the time. Badesim also revealed the salon she went to closed only two months after her incident, although she did not find out why. My family asked meI wanted to sue and they said they would respect my decision and me being , I feel like I was very naïve, she explained. I knew that the lady who was waxing me had a young daughter and I didnapost want her to suffer because of her mumaposs mistakes. But now looking back at it, thataposs not how it works and I should have sued. Not even because of the fact that she burned me but because of the fact that she made a -year-old girl feel like she was making a big deal and that she was guilty for being in pain. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. story: We are excited to announce a new home for the Evening Express content online, with a bigger and better website in partnership with The Press and Journal. We have spoken to our readers, and our aim is to deliver you everything that you need to know, together in one place.If you are a subscriber or thinking about joining our digital community, find out what it means for you below.In order to give you access to the news that you need, we have expanded our newsrooms and created dedicated news teams to serve you and our extended local communities across Aberdeen, Aberdeenshire, the Highlands and Islands and the North and North-East of Scotland. We will deliver you more content, live news as it happens, as well as breaking crime news and the latest from court, together in one place. We have also found new ways of telling our stories online, from in-depth investigations through to full- documentaries and podcasts.There is no change to The Press and Journal and the Evening Express newspaper or ePapers. The newspapers will continue to be available for purchase at your local store, delivered to your home, or as an ePaper . We will continue to deliver you the best stories in print, that you have come to expect from the PJ and the Evening Express.Our ePapers are a full replica version of the newspaper, published online,  days a week. You can access the PJ and the Evening Express ePaper via our dedicated ePaper apps where you can save and share stories, access all the paper supplements easily via their dedicated menu and even play interactive puzzles!If you would like to find out more about subscribing to the PJ or the Evening Express ePaper, please contact our Digital News Subscriptions Team on Your subscription to the Press and Journal will allow you to access all of the Evening Express stories which are now available on the PJ website. All of the best Evening Express content, including columnists and football analysis will now appear on the PJ website and will be available for you as part of your subscription.If you have an ePaper subscription there will be no change as to how you access your Press and Journal ePaper.The new website is now live. title: red star stung late in exciting league match
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwards.RJD-sponsored Red Star welcomed Baljaffray to the Joint Campus G pitch last Saturday where the sides played out a thrilling three-all draw in a match which swung in either direction in horrendous conditions.The sides exchanged goals in the first half, with Stuart MacLean reacting quickest in the box after the Baljaffray keeper couldn’t hold a Fraser Talbot shot and the striker scored to net his eleventh goal in eight games.Baljaffray forced a succession of corners near the end of the half and were on level terms when Red Star were only able to partially clear a corner which fell to the away side’s full back and his shot via the aid of a deflection went past young Leon Murphy in the Star goal. -Into the second half and Star could have retaken the lead when Aaron Moore latched onto a drilled cross from strike partner Stuart MacLean, however, his effort was blocked by an excellent save from the Baljaffray number one.The visitors took the lead after  minutes when a cross caused confusion in the Star defence and the Baljaffray forward had the simple task of finishing into an empty net from close range.Star huffed and puffed for an equaliser, however, they were frustrated by excellent goalkeeping until the goal came in fortuitous circumstances after a long ball was nodded past his own keeper by the Baljaffray centre back meaning the sides were level with  minutes to go.Star took the lead with five minutes remaining when Aaron Moore was able to burst clear of the Baljaffray backline and finish well into the far corner to make it -.This should have been enough to see Star over the line but Baljaffray scrambled a late equaliser when Star again failed to clear a free kick and the ball was bundled over the line to see the match end -.Lochgilphead Red Star are on their travels on Saturday November  when they face their toughest test of the season so far as they take on league leaders and title favourites Arthurlie.

title: local-primary-school-children-raise-funds-poppy-scotland
story: PUPILS at St. Maryrsquos Primary School in Melrose have paid their own special tribute to former pupils who lost their lives during WW in addition to raising money for the charity Poppy Scotland in its centenary year.All of the children have been busy working in their own little poppy factory from painting sheets and sheets of crimson paper to assembling our poppies.They also researched the  young men who spent their schooldays at St. Maryrsquos and ultimately died in that war and were able to find images of  of them.These images were then inserted into large painted poppies.Head of Art at the school Debbie Wood told us: ldquoIt felt appropriate to send these precious photographs back out into the world for people to see over  years later.ldquoWe do so hope that this sparks further conversation and who knows we might find a little more information regarding these young men. title: jim-telfers-contribution-world-rugby-recognised
story: BORDERS rugby legend Jim Telfer is to be inducted into World Rugbyrsquos Hall of Fame .The former Hawick High School and Gala Academy headmaster won  caps for Scotland,  as captain.And he made eight test appearances for the British and Irish Lions, on two tours, in  and .A tenacious back-row forward for Melrose, Telfer has the distinction of being the only Scotland international to have played New Zealand, South Africa and Australia without losing.Following his playing career, he became one of the most revered coaches in the game.He coached the Lions on their  tour to New Zealand, Scotland to the Five Nations Grand Slam in  and, as assistant to Sir Ian McGeechan, to a second Grand Slam in .After a break from coaching, Telfer was invited by McGeechan to become forwards coach on the triumphant Lions tour of South Africa in .Through his technical know-how and stirring motivational speeches, Telfer galvanised a Lions pack written off by the press and they laid the  for a - series victory.Telfer, with the assistance of John Rutherford and Hugh Campbell, was successful again in  as Scotland claimed the last-ever Five Nations title under their management.The six stars were selected by the Hall of Fame committee. This comprises of John Eales, David Hands, Henri Garcia, Pablo Mamone, Rob Cole, Anna Richards and Wayne Smith.Eales, the chair of the committee, said: ldquoThe  inductees for the World Rugby Hall of Fame are representative of all that is good in our game. Each of them have been outstanding players in either sevens or s and they have also been important contributors to rugby, in their own countries and globally, off the field.
