The services allow people to stand with others who have experienced the similar trauma of baby loss, and collectively acknowledge and remember each le lost.A parent who attended one of the lsquosaying goodbyersquo services said: ldquoThe service gave me the time and space to formally recognise all of my babies and the experience of being with people who knew how it felt was a real strength.ldquoAs I stood with other parents and proudly rang the bell for my  babies, I felt unbearable sadness but also a great privilege in being able to properly celebrate their existence.ldquoFor the first time, I felt my tears of grief, loss and love were allowed, shared and understood. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentComments: Our rulesWe want our comments to be a lively and valuable part of our community - a place where readers can debate and engage with the most important local issues. title: mps back watered down proposals ban paid consultancy work
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityMPs voted down Labourrsquos plans to introduce new rules to curb their outside business interests, something which has increased tensions between Boris Johnson and Tory backbenchers.Labourrsquos proposals called for a ban on ldquoany paid work to provide services as a parliamentary strategist, adviser or consultant.Crucially, it also included provisions requiring the Commons Standards Committee to come forward with proposals to implement the ban and guaranteeing time on the floor of the House for MPs to debate and vote on them.In contrast, the more vaguely worded Government amendment simply described the consultancy ban as ldquothe basis of a viable approach and supports the work of the Standards Committee to update the MPsrsquo code of conduct.Labourrsquos motion was rejected by  votes to , majority .While the Governmentrsquos amendment on standards was approved by  votes to zero, majority .No Labour MPs backed the amendment, but the ision list showed four Conservative MPs rebelled to support Labourrsquos motion ndash Peter Bone , Philip Hollobone , Nigel Mills , and Dan Poulter .Speaking after the vote, Labour leader Sir Keir Starmer said: ldquoWe put forward a plan of action to clean up politics and strengthen standards in politics. vw,vw,px, px"Labour leader Sir Keir Starmer speaks during Prime Ministerrsquos Questions in the House of Commons, London ldquoAndyou can believe it, after two weeks of Tory sleaze and corruption, the Prime Minister whipped his MPs against that plan of action, and, frankly, he just doesnrsquot get.Sir Keir said: ldquoWe are not going to back down from these proposals, wersquore not prepared to have them watered down, so we will press on with them. But it is unbelievable..removeUnder the Governmentrsquos proposals, set out in a letter to Commons Speaker Sir Lindsay Hoyle, rules would be updated to include two key recommendations from the Committee on Standards in Public Lersquos report on MPsrsquo outside interests from .These include changing the code of conduct so that any outside work should be ldquowithin reasonable limits and ldquonot prevent them from fully carrying out their duties.Those who failed to comply should be ldquoinvestigated and appropriately punished.I have written to the Commons Speaker to propose: The Code of Conduct for MPs is updated MPs who are prioritising outside interests over their constituents are investigated and appropriately punished MPs are banned from acting as paid political consultants or lobbyists pic SSQqrKRCGmdash Boris JohnsonNovember , The changes would also ban MPs from accepting paid work as a parliamentary strategist, adviser or consultant, and from accepting payment or offers of employment to act as political consultants.A Government spokesperson said: ldquoThe House of Commons has tonight voted to update the Code of Conduct for MPs.ldquoThis means that MPs will be banned from acting as paid political consultants or lobbyists and that MPs are always prioritising their constituents.ldquoThis will strengthen our parliamentary system and we will work on a cross-party basis to achieve this.But Chris Bryant, the Labour chairman of the Committee on Standards, replied to the statement on Twitter saying: ldquoExcept it doesnrsquot mean that. We havenrsquot changed anything yet.Mr Bryant then added in a statement that he hoped to have a final report on the committeersquos proposed changes ready to present to the Commons in early .He said: ldquoAny changes to the code would then require the Government to table the necessary motions and allow time for a debate on the floor of the House.The changes are likely to deepen tensions between Tory MPs.Earlier, Sir Geoffrey Clton-Brown, treasurer of the  Committee, said there was ldquodissatisfaction with the Prime Minister in the Tory ranks.And speaking to GB News, former minister Johnny Mercer said: ldquoThere are serious problems in the quality of our politics at the moment.The Tory MP for Plymouth Moor View, who has been outspoken against the Government since losing his job as veterans minister, added that he had ldquono relationship with Mr Johnson, despite initially backing him as leader.While Sir Keir said: ldquoIrsquove been really struck by how many Tory MPs seem to have lost faith and confidence in the Prime Minister.ldquoIt was noticeable at Prime Ministerrsquos Questions today that their benches were with many gaps, many MPs hadnrsquot turned up to support him.However, Mr Johnson was greeted at the  Committee of backbench MPs on Wednesday evening, prior to the vote, to loud banging on the tables in approval.It was reported that he told MPs ldquoon a clear road I crashed the car into a ditch in the saga surrounding former Tory MP Owen Paterson, who was found to have breached lobbying rules.But one backbencher said that the vast majority of questions at the meeting were surrounding the issue of small boats and immigration. vw,vw,px, px"Prime Minister Boris Johnson giving evidence to the Liaison Committee at the House of Commons, London Earlier on Wednesday, Mr Johnson admitted the initial effort to shield Mr Paterson from immediate suspension to enable a review of his case and the disciplinary process had been an error.ldquoThe intention genuinely was not to exonerate anybody, the intention was to see whether there was some way in which, on a cross-party basis, we could improve the system, Mr Johnson told the Liaison Committee of senior MPs.ldquoIn retrospect it was obviously, obviously mistaken to think we could conflate the two things and do I regret that decision ldquoYes I certainly do.Mr Paterson quit as an MP rather than face a vote on his suspension after the Government abandoned its bid to shield him from an immediate sanction.The PM also insisted he wanted to find a cross-party approach to the Westminster sleaze rows but became involved in spiky Commons exchanges with Sir Keir during PMQs over his own outside earnings as a lawyer prior to becoming Labour leader.The Speaker repeatedly ordered Mr Johnson to stop asking Sir Keir questions and said the exchanges had been ldquoill-tempered, adding: ldquoI need this House to gain respect but it starts by iniduals showing respect for title: archbishop canterbury apologises comments late bishop
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityJustin Welby said he was ldquowrong for not retracting a statement which said a ldquosignicant cloud is left over Bishop George Bellrsquos name.Mr Bell, the former bishop of Chichester who died in , was accused of abusing a woman in the s when she was aged between five and eight.The claims led the Church to issue an apology and pay pound, in compensation.A personal statement regarding Bishop George Bell:https:t.co HUetkydmdash Archbishop of CanterburyNovember , A report into how the Church handled the allegations, led by Lord Carlile of Berriew, was published in December  and criticised the Church for being too quick to accept the allegations of the complainant ldquowithout serious investigation or inquiry.After the report was published, the Archbishop of Canterbury issued a statement which said: ldquoThe complaint about Bishop Bell does not diminish the importance of his great achievement. We realise that a signicant cloud is left over his name.Mr Welby has now apologised for the comment.In a new statement issued on Wednesday, he said: ldquo[The]hellipposthumous allegations made against Bishop George Bell were taken seriously and investigated fully.ldquoI do not apologise for that, but as I have said before, we did not manage our response to the original allegation with the consistency, clarity or accountability that meets the high standards rightly demanded of us. I recognised the hurt that has been done as a consequence, and I have apologised unreservedly for the mistakes made in this process.ldquoWhat I say today that is new and should have been said sooner is this: I do not consider there to be a lsquosignicant cloudrsquo over Bishop George Bellrsquos name. vw,vw,px, px"Bishop George Bell .removeHe added: ldquoPreviously I refused to retract that statement and I was wrong to do so. I took that view because of the importance we rightly place on listening to those who come forward with allegations of abuse, and the duty of care we owe to them.ldquoBut we also owe a duty of care to those who are accused. I apologise for the hurt that my refusal to retract that statement has caused to Bishop Bellrsquos surviving relatives, colleagues and longstanding supporters.A second review was launched after the Church of England handed ldquofresh information to Sussex Police about Mr Bell in January .It was carried out by senior ecclesiastical lawyer Timothy Briden, the vicar general of Canterbury.The Churchrsquos national safeguarding team published its findings of the second inquiry in January  and said the new allegations were ldquounfounded..push,i[r].l*new Dateas,ms[]a.asynca.srcgmgagagagagagagagagagaga, title: Archbishop of Canterbury apologises for comments about late bishop article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log  s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"commentComments: Our rulesWe want our comments to be a lively and valuable part of our community - a place where readers can debate and engage with the most important local issues. title: mps vote against ban on second jobs as paid lobbyists as labour motion rejected
story: Man and woman arrested after woman seriously injured in Craigavon last seen in Craigavon area" href"https:www.portadowntimes news people ethan-carville-missing-boy--last-seen-in-craigavon-area- itm_sourceparsely-api" data-el"right" data-s-el"right" data-direction"right"    last seen in Craigavon area" href"https:www.portadowntimes news people ethan-carville-missing-boy--last-seen-in-craigavon-area- itm_sourceparsely-api" data-el"left" data-s-el"right" data-direction"right"Ethan Carville: Missing boylast seen in Craigavon areaNewsTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsBusinessEducationHealthPeopleRead ThisCoronavirusSportFootballOther SportWhats OnArts and EntertainmentThings To DoHomes and GardensLestyleCarsHomes and GardensPublic NoticesAdvertise My BusinessFree Happy AdsNewsMPs vote against ban on second jobs as paid lobbyists as Labour motion rejectedBy Heather CarrickWednesday, th November , : pmUpdated Wednesday, th November , : pm  "       "  " "" width"" srcset" images-i.jpimedia.uk imagefetch https:jpgreatcontent wp-content uploads   GettyImages-.jpg width w,  images-i.jpimedia.uk imagefetch https:jpgreatcontent wp-content uploads   GettyImages-.jpg width w,  images-i.jpimedia.uk imagefetch https:jpgreatcontent wp-content uploads   GettyImages-.jpg width w" layout"intrinsic" class"i-amphtml-layout-intrinsic i-amphtml-layout-size-defined" i-amphtml-layout"intrinsic"" fallback layout"responsive" "" width"" src" img placeholder.png" class"i-amphtml-layout-responsive i-amphtml-layout-size-defined" i-amphtml-layout"responsive"Boris Johnsons government has drafted a Labour motion to ban second jobs as paid lobbyists. A motion to ban MPs from holding second jobs outside parliament as paid lobbyists or political consultants has failed. MPs voted by a majority of  votes to reject the motion which had been put forward by the Labour Party following the recent Tory sleaze row and the government’s handling of the Owen Paterson case. Boris Johnson had instructed his MPs to vote against the Labour motion, with a following Conservative amendment passing through a majority of  votes. Labour leader Keir Starmer announced that the party would be tabling a motion to call for a ban on MPs being able to hold “any paid work to provide services as a parliamentary strategist, adviser or consultant”. It came after huge backlash over the Owen Paterson row and the accusation that the Conservative government had ed to a policy of “sleaze”. Johnson had previously instructed Tory MPs to vote against the immediate suspension of former MP Owen Paterson, who had been found by the parliamentary standards committee to have broken lobbying rules while working as a consultant and earning £, per year. The committee had recommended that Paterson serve a -day suspension, however his suspension was initially blocked after a vote in the House of Commons, where a reform of the parliamentary standards committee was also voted through. The government was forced to do a hard u-turn on blocking Paterson’s suspension following intense backlash from opposition parties and the public, with critics claiming that the incident had heralded ato “Tory sleaze”. As a result of the incident, Labour took the opportunity to table a motion which banned the paid employment of MPs in positions consultancy and advisory role outside of parliament. At a vote in the House of Commons on  November, the motion was rejected by  votes to . Despite rejecting the motion with a majority of  votes, the vote showed that Boris Johnson’s majority on the issue had decreased. Many Tory MPs abstained from voting against the controversial motion, while four Conservative MPs - Peter bone, Philip Hollobone, Nigel Mills and Dan Poulter - rebelled against the party and voted in favour of the ban on certain kinds of second jobs. Upon the announcement that a Labour backed motion calling for a ban on paid lobbying and consultancy role for MP would be tabled, Johnson tabled an amendment. The amendment described the ban as “the basis of a viable approach” and called on the Standards Committee to update the MPs’ Code of Conduct. Labour called the motion a “watered down” version of the original amendment. Despite the original motion being rejected, the amendment passed with  votes to zero, with Labour MPs abstaining from the second vote. A Government spokesperson said: “The House of Commons has tonight voted to update the Code of Conduct for MPs.“This means that MPs will be banned from acting as paid political consultants or lobbyists and that MPs are always prioritising their constituents.“This will strengthen our parliamentary system and we will work on a cross-party basis to achieve this.”Following the vote and rejection of the Labour motion, Starmer said: “We put forward a plan of action to clean up politics and strengthen standards in politics.“Andyou can believe it, after two weeks of Tory sleaze and corruption, the Prime Minister whipped his MPs against that plan of action, and, frankly, he just doesn’t get.”“We are not going to back down from these proposals, we’re not prepared to have them watered down, so we will press on with them.“But it is unbelievable.”

title: swann welcomes vaccine passport decision
story: A range of sustained actions are needed to drive down Northern Ireland’s Covid- infection rate, Health Minister Robin Swann has emphasised. The Executive today backed proposals to introduce vaccine passports. Its believed they will be needed to enter nightclubs, hospitality venues which serve food and drink cinemas, theatres, concert halls and conference centres indoor events with  or more attendees with some or all of the audience not normally seated outdoor events with , or more attendees with some or all of the audience not normally seated and events where more than , people will be present regardless of whether they are seated. All of the Executive parties, with the exception of the DUP, backed the proposals. Welcoming the Executive’s decision to introduce Covid certication for hospitality settings, the Minister said: “Certication must be seen as one piece in a jigsaw of required measures. Other measures include signicantly increased use of face coverings, more people working from home and more social distancing. We need to limit our contacts and always be mindful of the importance of fresh air and good ventilation in dispersing Covid- particles. “We also need to continue the acceleration of our vaccine booster roll-out, and keep encouraging more people to come forward for their first and second doses. “The case for Covid certication in hospitality is not complicated. It can reduce the number of infected people in high risk settings. Vaccinated people are less likely to become infected and ill than unvaccinated people. And the virus is only transmitted by infected people. “Our Covid numbers are too high and we need to forcibly push them down. Our health and social care system is under severe stress. We have to act. “Let me also emphasise that I do not want to see further Covid restrictions on our economy or our daily lives. Such a decision is far from inevitable. “We can all play our part in altering the direction of this pandemic. It is in all our hands. “By following public health advice we can help keep each other safe and support our health workers. “We all want this pandemic to be over, but simply wishing it away is never going to be enough. A united effort across society is what is needed to get us through this winter.” Covid certication requires proof of full vaccination status, or a negative Lateral Flow Test in the previous  hours, or
